name: Return

aliases.name: ReturnF
aliases.type: Return.Return msg model -> Return.Return msg model

values.comment:
Go point free with `andThen` chaining. Looking at the example from `andThen`

```elm
resulting : Return msg { model | bar : Int }
resulting = myReturn
    |> andThen foo
    |> andThen foo
    |> andThen foo
```

this code roughly becomes:

```elm
doFoo3Times : { model | bar : Int } -> Return msg { model | bar : Int }
doFoo3Times =
  foo >>> foo >>> foo
```
values.type: (b -> Return.Return msg c) -> (a -> Return.Return msg b) -> a -> Return.Return msg c
(a -> Return.Return msg b) -> (b -> Return.Return msg c) -> a -> Return.Return msg c

values.name: andMap
values.comment: Map an `Return` into a `Return` containing a `Model` function
values.type: Return.Return msg (a -> b) -> Return.Return msg a -> Return.Return msg b

values.name: andThen
values.comment:
Chain together expressions from `Model` to `Return`.

```elm
-- arbitrary function to demonstrate
foo : Model -> Return Msg Model
foo ({bar} as model) =
  -- forking logic
  if bar < 10
  -- that side effects may be added
  then (model, getAjaxThing)
  -- that the model may be updated
  else ({model | bar = model.bar - 2 }, Cmd.none)
```

They are now chainable with `andThen`...

```elm
resulting : Return msg { model | bar : Int }
resulting = myReturn
    |> andThen foo
    |> andThen foo
    |> andThen foo
```

Here we changed up `foo` three times, but we can use any function of
type `(a -> Return msg b)`.

Commands will be accumulated automatically as is the case with all
functions in this library.
values.type: (a -> Return.Return msg b) -> Return.Return msg a -> Return.Return msg b

values.name: command
values.comment: Add a `Cmd` to a `Return`, the `Model` is uneffected
values.type: Platform.Cmd.Cmd msg -> Return.ReturnF msg model

values.name: dropCmd
values.comment: Drop the current `Cmd` and replace with an empty thunk
values.type: Return.ReturnF msg model

values.name: effect_
values.comment: Add a `Cmd` to a `Return` based on its `Model`, the `Model` will not be effected
values.type: Respond.Respond msg model -> Return.ReturnF msg model

values.name: flatten
values.type: Return.Return msg (Return.Return msg model) -> Return.Return msg model

values.name: map
values.comment: Transform the `Model` the `Cmd` will be left untouched
values.type: (a -> b) -> Return.Return msg a -> Return.Return msg b

values.name: map2
values.comment:
Combine 2 `Return`s with a function

```elm
map2
  (\modelA modelB -> { modelA | foo = modelB.foo })
  retA
  retB
```
values.type: (a -> b -> c) -> Return.Return msg a -> Return.Return msg b -> Return.Return msg c

values.name: map3
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d) -> Return.Return msg a -> Return.Return msg b -> Return.Return msg c -> Return.Return msg d

values.name: map4
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e) -> Return.Return msg a -> Return.Return msg b -> Return.Return msg c -> Return.Return msg d -> Return.Return msg e

values.name: map5
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f) -> Return.Return msg a -> Return.Return msg b -> Return.Return msg c -> Return.Return msg d -> Return.Return msg e -> Return.Return msg f

values.name: mapBoth
values.comment:
Map over both the model and the msg type of the `Return`.
This is useful for easily embedding a `Return` in a Union Type.
For example

```elm
import Foo

type Msg = Foo Foo.Msg
type Model = FooModel Foo.Model

...

update : Msg -> Model -> Return Msg Model
update msg model =
   case msg of
     Foo foo -> Foo.update foo model.foo
      |> mapBoth Foo FooModel
```
values.type: (a -> b) -> (c -> d) -> Return.Return a c -> Return.Return b d

values.name: mapCmd
values.type: (a -> b) -> Return.Return a model -> Return.Return b model

values.name: mapWith
values.comment: Transform the `Model` of and add a new `Cmd` to the queue
values.type: (a -> b) -> Platform.Cmd.Cmd msg -> Return.Return msg a -> Return.Return msg b

values.name: pipel
values.type: List (Return.ReturnF msg model) -> Return.ReturnF msg model

values.name: piper
values.type: List (Return.ReturnF msg model) -> Return.ReturnF msg model

values.name: return
values.type: model -> Platform.Cmd.Cmd msg -> Return.Return msg model

values.name: sequence
values.type: List (Return.Return msg model) -> Return.Return msg (List model)

values.name: singleton
values.type: model -> Return.Return msg model

values.name: zero
values.type: Return.ReturnF msg model

aliases.name: Respond
aliases.comment:
A function from a model to a Cmd.
Basically there are times where you want to
have a side effect on the world if the model
has a certain shape. `Respond` facilitates
this use case.

values.name: append
values.type: Respond.Respond msg a -> Respond.Respond msg a -> Respond.Respond msg a

values.name: comap
values.comment:
Add a function to the front
`b -> a >> a -> Cmd msg`
values.type: (b -> a) -> Respond.Respond msg a -> Respond.Respond msg b

values.name: sum
values.type: List (Respond.Respond msg a) -> Respond.Respond msg a

values.name: zero
values.type: Respond.Respond msg a
